text: I got a DM asking what happened to the implied volatility today in GameStop after the shareholder meeting and you know if it's about some options, I'm here for it. So exactly what we're going to talk about today because interestingly enough, that volatility didn't bleed out as much as I expected, which makes me believe there might be something else that the market is looking at, which we'll take a look at. While I was at it, a couple of the updates that I saw were in Kitty dropping his standard cryptic messages with no captions at all, you guys are really, really good at interpreting what these mean. I am not. I don't know all the details yet. I did look up both of these quickly and this dude was complaining about the repping at some tennis matches and then this guy apparently is from a Disney movie that he can see the future and people are really reading into this green reflection, although he looks super sad to me. So I don't know what to make of either of those. You guys will have to tell me. But let's talk about this real quick too. This is from Ryan Cohen after the shareholders meeting and it seemed interesting because on Twitter, it seemed like a lot of people were expecting this big rallying cry from Cohen. And to me, at least this is a very standard shareholder's meeting update where they're just talking about broad brush strokes.

So yesterday, we saw the put side of this front expiration, the IV severely depressed. That typically leads to a upward price sensitivity, meaning we're pricing in more vols to the upside. This is now turned into almost a standard volatility smile. Slight calls skew still in terms of the vols, but not massive. This is way more normal. So if you compare this to the video I did yesterday, you'll see a huge difference between these. And this is exactly how vol adjusts based on current market conditions. Now, if you look at the following expiration, 28 June, we see something different again. We see that same kind of call skew that we saw yesterday. So this is again, the market very clearly pricing in more vols to the upside, pricing in more upside. And so this is just looking at the front two expirations and a lot of this volume for both of them, actually the majority of the volume that we're seeing across all contracts were in these front two, which again is interesting to me. And there is a lot of volume here at the 30s, which I think we saw which was this block here. So not dead, meaning there's still a lot of people playing in these really short term expirations, which is very interesting to me. If you're interested from a retail trade and perspective, why that can be really, really dangerous, check out the last video I did. I'll throw it in the notes below because I think that's super important for new traders to be aware of that buying far out of the money options seems really attractive, but it's not as attractive as you might think it is. And you should just be aware whether you still want to trade them or not. That's obviously totally up to you. You seemingly are grown people as you should be slaying in trades however you feel like it, but it should be at least informed. We should know the trade off. So that's the goal
